data.title: ‎‘Bud's Recruit’ review by Lencho of the Apes • Letterboxd
data.meta_description: I'm pretty sure there was no way King Vidor could have explicitly challenged the jingo patriotism that accompanied the war effort, but it sure is easy to read this bad boy against the grain; the throwing of shade begins in the very first scene, conflating a recruitment drive with a gaggle of boys playing make-believe bootcamp and going through the motions of pretend drills and storybook manouevres, all leading up to an attack on a strawman labelled THE KAISUR. Later there's pacifists and debate and nuance... and a restored-to-normativity ending with the wussyboy enlisting after all.
data.text:
I'm pretty sure there was no way King Vidor could have explicitly challenged the jingo patriotism that accompanied the war effort, but it sure is easy to read this bad boy against the grain; the throwing of shade begins in the very first scene, conflating a recruitment drive with a gaggle of boys playing make-believe bootcamp and going through the motions of pretend drills and storybook manouevres, all leading up to an attack on a strawman labelled THE KAISUR.

Later there's pacifists and debate and nuance... and a restored-to-normativity ending with the wussyboy enlisting after all.
